item.title: Return Oriented Programming
item.description:
Return-Oriented Programming (ROP) â€“ A Beginner’s Journey

So recently, I finally took the dive into Return-Oriented Programming (ROP) and wanted to document my experience. Not just for anyone else learning, but also for future me when I inevitably forget how I did this in a week.

This post is based on a simple binary exploitation flow, and I followed along with the John Hammond Misfortune CTF ROP video. Highly recommend checking that out if you’re just getting into this.

item.title: Welcome to My Cybersecurity Blog
item.description:
ğŸ‘‹ Hello and Welcome!

I’m Talen Neil Serrao, a graduate in Cybersecurity and Ethical Hacking from Coventry University ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§ â€” awarded First Class Honours. This blog is where I share my journey, experiments, and insights in the world of cybersecurity.

ğŸ§  What Youâ€™ll Find Here

  • ğŸ” Writeups of penetration testing labs and challenges (e.g. TryHackMe, HackTheBox)
  • ğŸ› ï¸ Projects Iâ€™ve built â€” from reverse engineering tools to AI-enhanced detection systems
  • ğŸ§¬ Deep dives into buffer overflows, ROP chains, DoS attacks, and secure protocols
  • ğŸ” Insights on cryptography, exploit development, and ethical hacking techniques

ğŸ§° Tech I Use

  • Languages: Python, Bash, C, C++, JavaScript
  • Tools: Ghidra, Metasploit, Cutter, Wireshark, Burp Suite, Scapy, Pwntools
  • AI/ML: Neural networks with PyTorch for attack classification
  • Protocols: TCP/IP, DNS, HTTPS, Wi-Fi, and encrypted comms using AES-GCM

ğŸš€ Why I Built This Site

To document and reflect on my learning, give back to the community, and stay sharp by sharing knowledge publicly. Cybersecurity is a fast-evolving field, and I believe in learning by doing â€” and teaching.
